'...and then global economic collapse.'

Don't forget WWII.
Maybe the Republicans are actually read their  history and recognize that the best way to ruin the economy and thus better their chances of regaining power is to use Mellon's strategy.
I think it was George Bernard Shaw who came up with that "bon mots."

Who was it that said "History repeats itself...the first time as tragedy, the second time as farce"?

Yesterday, I was looking at a biography of Andrew Mellon--Hoover's Treasury Secretary--who is perhaps best known for advising Hoover that the best way to respond the Great Depression was to "liquidate labor, liquidate stocks, liquidate farmers, liquidate real estate… it will purge the rottenness out of the system. High costs of living and high living will come down. People will work harder, live a more moral life. Values will be adjusted, and enterprising people will pick up from less competent people."

Perhaps less well known is the fact that he was the original supply sider--arguing that lowering the top tax rate to 17%, cutting the estate tax and cutting government spending were the keys to prosperity and growth.

It is as if he wrote--or at least inspired the economic policies of the Republicans in this country and conservative members of the Merkel hair shirt society.

I'm had pressed to fathom why his adherents fail to grasp the fact that the twelve years he ran the U.S. Treasury--1921 to 1932--played out almost exactly like the last decade-- massive tax cuts for the richest Americans, growing income equality, wealth-driven speculative bubbles in real estate and stocks, a historic rise in household debt and then global economic collapse.

Why, Paul, do you stick to the idea, Paul, that it is okay to spend what you don't produce. Okay, so Spain wasn't as profligate as some other nations. But a 60% debt to GDP ratio should really be nothing to sneeze at. Couple that type of overspending with truly profligate real estate and banking sectors and you clearly have the formula for a depressed economy.
Merkel is absolutely right: the answer to 20 years of non-value-based spending is not to have those who are still creating value prop up an unsustainable system. Just like the credit boom in the 1990s in the US, Europe had a spending boom at the same time with the euphoric launch of the EU. But this was a bubble, not based on real value creation. The bubble has burst. And Europeans have to readjust their expectations, get off their subsidized keisters and find satisfaction again in creating real value.
This lesson, of course, also applies here in the US.
But somehow there is not a single politician or op-ed writer who dares to say that the system is bust and that the only way out is for people to find ways to make do with much less by contenting themselves with the creation of productive value.

But a possible reality is that small incremental steps will be left far behind and irrelevant by catastrophic events. History does not always favor incrementalists. For one thing there has to be a strong basis to increment from. It's not clear that is the case in Europe (or in the US)

Incremental-ism is the luxury of those who have already succeeded!

If you are saying, "she's going as fast as she can", then the reality may be that she will not be able to move Germany fast enough to avoid catastrophe for the Euro. But from an outside observer's perspective, it doesn't look like Merkel is trying very hard...
Seems to me that small incremental steps have been tried for the past three years. They haven't worked. Time for something big.

Let's be pragmatic, Dr. Krugman:

Merkel desperately does not want to be seen as having dug the grave of the Great European Experiment - the one designed to save the continent from another catastrophic war, the one representing the great moral break with Germany's belligerent past.

For better or worse, the Euro has become a cornerstone of that Great Experiment.

Clearly, Merkel - leading a shaky coalition into a general election in 2013 and repeatedly chastised by the country's Supreme Constitutional Court for rushing decisions through Parliament - has no choice but seek and implement a series of continuous progressive improvements to existing structures and policies. At least until consensus-building within Europe produces a different set of political and economic realities,

Therefore, Dr, Krugman, far more productive than insisting on reality-defying, quick-paced major change, it might be more valuable to advocate for an effective set of small but coherent steps designed to walk the continent back from the financial abyss, arrest further economic depression and restart employment.

Surely, you and your colleagues can make such a contribution.

You have miscast all the European actors you use in your analogy. It might be more accurate had you applied this to the US, esp. after the Wall St. fiasco in 2008. If you think there isn't a social divide, if you want to call it that, in the US, you haven't been paying attention.

The perceived foot-dragging by Merkel is to push, cajole, frighten, and whatever else she can do to get southern European governments to reform their systems. The corruption is of those local elites, not some Europe wide elite system. If she appears willing to just 'hand it over', they have no motivation to reform.

Of course, Germany wants to give up as little as possible. Who wouldn't? German economists and those in Brussels know very well that the more economically stable and prosperous those southern economies are, the more German exports they will buy.

It appears the German game is to drag their feet as much as possible to give up as little as possible. The imagined result is that the hoped-for global economic recovery will carry the troubled nation's economies upward and the German economy will not be impinged upon.

Can we say, "Rising tide carries (southern European) boats higher?" We know how that delusion ends.

My maternal grandmother, a Scot, lived with us for ten years. She had been a young lady during WW I. In my early teens, I asked her year by year about WW I.

When I asked her who they thought would win in 1917, her reply was a surprise, "Liam, in 1917, only kings and generals cared who'd win. The rest of us just wanted the slaughter to end."

That social divide is an integral part of European culture and behavior. The wealthy elite consider themselves royal, above it all and untouchable, and view the commoners as expendable water carriers for what the elite think ought to be done. In this case, it's preserve the purchasing power of the wealth of the elite.

I don't see morality in this at all, only indifference to wide-spread, perhaps global, harm, and propaganda inflaming nationalist hate to support arrogant foot-dragging.

I'll take the 70s era Dutch or the 50s Hungarians in that discussion before I would admit the 1982 Brazilians. Yes, they scored some great goals in 1982, but that was a side that just...could...NOT...defend. 5 matches played, and one clean sheet kept, against New Zealand. They conceded first in three of their five matches. I know, I saw every match in person. The first goal they allowed, against the Soviet Union, was a horrible goalkeeping folly, a shot from the touch line almost 40 yards from goal that bounced, and bounced off of goalie Waldir Peres and into the net. And the penultimate goal that Brazil conceded that tournament, having leveled Italy in a match in which they only needed a draw, Toninho Cerezo, who otherwise had a marvelous tournament in midfield, mistakenly squared a pass right to Paolo Rossi who took it in and easily beat Peres again to give Italy a halftime lead. In today's game, either of those goals would get players benched and/or managers sacked. Brazil likely could have survived Peres dismal goalkeeping had Careca been healthy, or had Tele Santana played Socrates as deep lying center forward other than the misfiring Serginho. But the combination of terrible #1 AND #9, abetted by two mediocre center halves in Oscar and Luizinho, precludes Brazil 1982 from being discussed as one of the great teams never to win. Seven greats is nice, but they would have been a champion with a Casillas, Buffon, or even Leao or Taffarel between the sticks...

Spain as the greatest team ever? Perhaps- they certainly have the results, and there is a certain unparalleled level of mastery of the game in their capacity to keep possession and put teams to the sword with such efficiency. Nevertheless great teams do not always achieve great results. There have been many teams Spain's equal in talent and their superior in flair that have faltered at the final hurdle by some twist in fortune. Without trying to be too nostalgic I think the Brazilians of 1982 and the Dutch of the 70s deserve to be in this discussion. Those Brazilians scored spectacular goals for fun in that World Cup tournament. They were breathtaking in a way totally unlike the Spaniards. RIP Socrates

You use the expression, non-immigrant worker, which I confess is a neat way to avoid using undocumented alien, or the actual true and accurate description, illegal alien immigrant. The inconveniences you detail are part of the process. Clearly if a person is fortunate to be admitted legally into the US, carrying what ever documents mandated by US law is a specific requirement that cannot be avoided, or if it is, one is not in compliance with US law, subject to whatever penalties are mandated by the US.

The simple fact is, if you are an illegal alien immigrant, you have broken US law; you have no right to be in the US. If you are hired to work, your employer breaks the law. If you misrepresent yourself to get a drivers license, or a Social Security card, you break the law.

Is it then so difficult to understand that the legal immigrant, obliged to carry whatever documents are specified by regulations to be in compliance with the law, is really not being imposed on in any way, simply to do the right thing ?

The immigration law needs to be updated and modern technology brought into play to enable legal immigrants to be safe in their country of choice while they wait for the specified period required on the path to citizenship. For illegal immigrants the competing factions will fight hard to support the various points of view.

The bottom line is the administration must seal the border with the able assistance of the states. Any other path is unacceptable and a failure.

A global database may evolve; after the Affordable Helath Care is implemented.

The technology is available; and all we need now is willingness and respect for ourselves and others...So a template for SS# system should be designed for all...and we should welcome immigrants. We are a national built upon immigration.

Sam, perhaps one way to deal with that problem is to issue two identical cards to each person. One to carry and one to keep with important papers. Problem is, for those of us who are organizationally impaired, just keeping track of ONE card can be a major challenge!

Perhaps a more streamlined way to replace a lost or stolen card within 24 hours?

Or we could just all get microchipped....

You presented some good ideas this morning though you overlooked the fact that legal immigrants, those holding so called Green Cards, have been obliged to have such identification on their person at all times. In my case, fifty years ago, it was not an imposition, and I carried it for six years until becoming a US citizen. In all that time, including during my service in the US Army, I was never asked to produce it, except on entering the US.

In the case of an illegal immigrant, there is no Green Card. Any Social Security card is fake or a duplicate and quite likely so is a drivers license. An employer who either does not use EVerify, or ignores its provisions must be prosecuted, no excuses, and hefty fines for violators.

My son recently changed employment and his new employer required an original Birth Certificate which they copied to place in his file, returning the original.

Constantly ignored and overlooked in this ongoing discussion is the plight of many millions of people throughout the globe who are being processed for US visas as part of the flow of legal immigrants. Sometimes it takes years for these people to complete the process and when admitted they are required to comply with the same strictures which were necessary fifty years ago. These people are patient and in compliance with US law and then when the arrive in the US have to compete with illegal immigrants who are already here and in possession of the very job the legal immigrant hoped to obtain.
